text: Patient: Don’t take the Ambien and the who again? Doctor: Restoril. This new sleeping pill. If I give you that… You know what, next time just bring all your Ambien pills and all that. Patient: Okay. I sure will. Doctor: That way, then I will give you the new sleeping pill prescription. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Okay but what I do in the meantime (laughs) Doctor: Well that’s why I was saying that well if there was somebody else with you, I’m concerned that you’re going to take both and it will be too much, it will zonk you out. Okay there’s nobody here with you even to tell for me to tell and the dangerous thing is you have your Ambiens at home. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you very well could make a mistake and take both, take the Ambien and the new sleeping pill. Patient: No I wouldn’t take the Ambien then. I’ll just throw them out. Doctor: You sure? Patient: Yeah I will pull them out.

text: Patient: Yeah, I hear that. Doctor: You can check with Dr. G___ Any notes from us - So let’s get a hold of your results from your most recent lung scan and your visit from pulmonology as to what they say or their thinking is behind your gasping spells. It’s important. Ah, your ARV7 is positive. That suggests that the Enzalutamide may not work very long. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s likely in the near future that you’ll need new belly scan, abdominal scan, bone scan for us to more directly determine that the Enzalutamide is not benefiting you. So we tried to get your tissue sent for molecular testing but when we sent it, it wasn’t adequate for that sort of evaluation, so Dr. G__ may look at other options. Sometimes they can do another biopsy or do a blood test, Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: but that’s not as good, but it’s something that’s easy, though. So once we’ve determined that your cancer has continued to grow, the standard therapy would be to move you to chemotherapy and if the name docetaxel based chemotherapy. Alternatively we’ve got two studies. I got rid of one as I wrote that. Patient: Right. Doctor: So the one is with Vitamin C. The one with the immune therapy. So I’m putting down an appointment for you to see me in a month. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You can check on my chart or you and Dr. G__ decide something earlier, or you need to see us earlier, the scans are made, you can see me earlier; that doesn’t mean I’m going to start you earlier. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But you know if it’s sort of you would rather do chemo with us rather than closer to home or if one of these studies makes sense, then we will be available or just to check in to sort of see where you are with some of these decision processes. Vital signs Your my chart, you’re already hooked in. These are the medicines I think you’re taking.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So in this study there is a random allocation of the therapy and random also means that neither the physician which is me nor the patient which is you knows So it truly is random. And also the computer program flips the coin so to speak, you can only flip it once, you can’t continue to flip over and over until you get the condition you want Patient: Okay. Doctor: So option one is what we call observation. Your option two is the stereotactic radiotherapy, which I mentioned is called SBRT for short. that in order to make this trial a little more attractive to patients is designed ins such a way that the odds of getting the radiotherapy are twice as high as the odds of getting the observation. So in other words, you can think of it as a three-headed coin, there’s a one out of three chance that you’re gonna get the observation group. That’s about a thirty-three percent chance. And there’s a two out of three chance or sixty-six percent that you will get the stereotactic radiotherapy which most people on this trial want to get. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it. Patient: Yeah. I understand. Doctor: So here with the observation we are SBRT and you have a crossover. The crossover goes from the observation group to the therapy group. Okay. The crossover is basically gonna happen whenever or if the PSA level decreases by fifty percent of baseline. Patient: The baseline meaning my initial baseline – have to begin with or the baseline for this? Doctor: Baseline for this trial. Patient: The baseline for this would be somewhere around twenty-eight. Doctor: Correct.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
